Greater Fireball Rune.hazardDisable: @Check[thievery|dc:25] (expert) to erase the rune without triggering the sensor, or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.9HpwDN4MYQJnW0LG]{Dispel Magic} (4th rank; counteract DC 23) to counteract the rune
Greater Fireball Rune.name: Greater Fireball Rune

Grim Rictus Bridge Guard.description:
Guards are rank-and-file members of a town watch or city guard, trained to look for trouble, take down criminals, and follow orders. They are a match for only the most fledgling of adventurers and criminals, but, given time, the settlement can usually muster them in numbers sufficient to neutralize most threats.

Larger societies rely on those with the authority and the ability to interpret and enforce laws. In good-aligned societies, these officials carry out their duties fairly. In neutral and evil ones, these officials can be harsh and cruel (with an altered alignment to reflect this), imposing severe punishments on those who can't pay for mercy.
Grim Rictus Bridge Guard.name: Grim Rictus Bridge Guard

Grim Rictus Robber.description:
Though not every commoner is downtrodden, many live hard lives of toil as they work to keep their families fed and housed in relative comfort. While many commoners are just simple folks who keep to themselves, sometimes commoners rebel, either rising up to face their oppressors or persuaded or even duped into joining nefarious plans and criminal conspiracies. Commoners benefit from power in numbers, and a crowd of commoners can accomplish a great deal more than their rulers often expect.

Unfortunately, every society has people living on its fringes. While good communities work to grant aid and respite to their downtrodden, sometimes-due to economic downturn, famine, or war-the ranks of the less fortunate exceed the community's capacity to support them. In heartless neutral and evil societies, poverty is seen as an inevitability that can never be truly eradicated, or even worse, as a tool to be manipulated for political gain.

T3ZpHsIT64RGyhT0.description: When three or more robbers are adjacent to each other each commoner gets a +1 circumstance bonus to Athletics checks to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.7blmbDrQFNfdT731]{Shove}, attack rolls, and damage rolls.
T3ZpHsIT64RGyhT0.name: Power of the Mob

lqVfEZu6MeCHDuky.name: Lore (any one related to their trade)

Grim Rictus Robber.name: Grim Rictus Robber

Growling Shadow Drake.description: Shadow drakes are typically among the smallest and least powerful of their species. Most stand as tall and long as house cats and have charcoal-colored scales and membranous wings just translucent enough to pass for shadows. Attracted to shiny materials, they employ deception, teamwork, and even rudimentary traps to create opportunities to make off with ill-gotten gains. Shadow drakes have a particular fascination and admiration for umbral dragons-a notable exception to the norm for drakes and dragons.

0VNX7MbrCqRSKYkE.description:
Trigger A creature attacks the shadow drake while it is in an area of dim light

Effect The shadow drake further obscures its position. The attacker must succeed at a @Check[flat|dc:11] check in order to affect the shadow drake, as if the drake were @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.iU0fEDdBp3rXpTMC]{Hidden} for the triggering attack.
0VNX7MbrCqRSKYkE.name: Shadow Evade

5IixHzakyftZgS0g.description:
Frequency three times per day

Effect The shadow drake Strides or Flies twice.
5IixHzakyftZgS0g.name: Speed Surge

QNy9Hrx2ib5tkQKt.description: The shadow drake's form shifts and blends reflexively with surrounding shadows. A shadow drake gains an additional reaction each round, but it can use this reaction only for Shadow Evade.
QNy9Hrx2ib5tkQKt.name: Shadow Blend

usIKpszaYrCWfN8r.description:
A shadow drake spits a ball of black liquid that explodes into a cloud of frigid black shadow. This attack has a range of 40 feet and explodes in a 5-foot-radius burst. Creatures within the burst take @Damage[(3d6-4)[cold]] damage (@Check[reflex|dc:16|basic] save). The explosion of shadow also snuffs out mundane light sources the size of a torch, lantern, or smaller, and attempts to counteract magical light with a +10 counteract modifier.

The shadow drake can't use Shadow Breath again for [[/r 1d6]] rounds.
usIKpszaYrCWfN8r.name: Shadow Breath

wnZi8QCOMG86Db4l.description: The shadow drake makes one bite Strike and two tail Strikes in any order.
wnZi8QCOMG86Db4l.name: Draconic Frenzy

Growling Shadow Drake.name: Growling Shadow Drake

Hallways Full of Even More Mostly Illuso.description: Several distressed opossums dressed in school uniforms and under the effects of @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.j8vIoIEWElvpwkcI]{Mirror Image} fly about the hallway, guided by four giggling sprites.
Hallways Full of Even More Mostly Illuso.hazardDisable: @Check[diplomacy|dc:23], @Check[deception|dc:23], or @Check[intimidation|dc:23] four times to convince one sprite to undo their spells; @Check[athletics|dc:25], @Check[diplomacy|dc:25] (with wild empathy) or @Check[nature|dc:25] to subdue or soothe the opossums; or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.9HpwDN4MYQJnW0LG]{Dispel Magic} (2nd rank; counteract DC 21) to undo one sprites' worth of spells. Four successes are required to disable the hazard.
Hallways Full of Even More Mostly Illuso.hazardRoutine: (4 actions) The hazard loses 1 action each turn for each Disable success. Each sprite takes one action to Strike a different randomly chosen PC.
Hallways Full of Even More Mostly Illuso.name: Hallways Full of Even More Mostly Illusory Opossums

Hallways Full of Mostly Illusory Opossum.description: Several distressed opossums dressed in school uniforms and under the effects of @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.j8vIoIEWElvpwkcI]{Mirror Image} fly about the hallway, guided by four giggling sprites.
Hallways Full of Mostly Illusory Opossum.hazardDisable: @Check[diplomacy|dc:20], @Check[deception|dc:20], or @Check[intimidation|dc:20] four times to convince one sprite to undo their spells; @Check[athletics|dc:22], @Check[diplomacy|dc:22] (with wild empathy) or @Check[nature|dc:22] to subdue or soothe the opossums; or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.9HpwDN4MYQJnW0LG]{Dispel Magic} (2nd rank; counteract DC 18) to undo one sprites' worth of spells. Four successes are required to disable the hazard.
Hallways Full of Mostly Illusory Opossum.hazardRoutine: (4 actions) The hazard loses 1 action each turn for each Disable success. Each sprite takes one action to Strike a different randomly chosen PC.

lVHVshcIoX6f8ybS.description:
Trigger Halran critically succeeds at a Strike or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.Dt6B1slsBy8ipJu9]{Disarm} with hisAldori dueling sword.

Effect Halran attempts to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.2u915NdUyQan6uKF]{Demoralize} the target of his Strike or Disarm. This Demoralize attempt does not have the auditory trait, nor does Halran take a penalty to the check if the target doesn't understand his language.
lVHVshcIoX6f8ybS.name: Unnerving Prowess

lVHVshcIoX6f8ybS.description:
Trigger Halran critically succeeds at a Strike or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.Dt6B1slsBy8ipJu9]{Disarm} with hisAldori dueling sword.

Effect Halran attempts to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.2u915NdUyQan6uKF]{Demoralize} the target of his Strike or Disarm. This Demoralize attempt does not have the auditory trait, nor does Halran take a penalty to the check if the target doesn't understand his language.
lVHVshcIoX6f8ybS.name: Unnerving Prowess

Harpy Forager.description:
Harpies are filthy amalgamations of human and bird, resembling feral humans with wings, talons, and mouths full of sharp teeth. They use captivating songs to lure creatures in, then murder them while they stand transfixed. They enjoy causing confusion and fear in their prey before they strike, believing it creates a savory flavor in the flesh. Harpies can eat most creatures but strongly prefer sapient prey-humans and elves are their favorite. Although harpies will eat goblins if sufficiently hungry, they dislike their flavor and avoid eating them if possible. This doesn't comfort goblins, of course, who have a particularly strong fear of harpies. Because their aeries often reek with the gore of their kills and careless spatters of guano, harpies carry a distinctly vile scent that canny travelers associate with danger. Harpies who roost close to civilization make better efforts to keep clean, though these efforts have mixed results.

Harpies live in family groups or larger clans. They are lightweight despite their size, standing 5 feet tall and weighing only around 90 pounds. While most use relatively simple weapons, some harpies take pride in learning and mastering the use of more complex tools of war such as swords and slings. Those who master the use of the bow, in particular, are often regarded as heroes among their kind and terrors among their victims.

NQF0fD75864Ytav1.description:
The harpy cries out an eerie, compelling melody. Each non-harpy creature within a @Template[emanation|distance:300]{300-foot aura} must attempt a @Check[will|dc:24] save to avoid becoming captivated by the harpy's song. The effect lasts for 1 round, but if the harpy uses this ability again on subsequent rounds, it extends the duration by 1 round for all affected creatures. Once a creature succeeds at any save against Captivating Song, that creature is temporarily immune to Captivating Songs for 24 hours.

Success The creature is unaffected.

Failure The creature is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.AdPVz7rbaVSRxHFg]{Fascinated}, and it must spend each of its actions to move closer to the harpy as expediently as possible, while avoiding obvious dangers. If a captivated creature is adjacent to the harpy, it stays still and doesn't act. If attacked by the harpy, the creature is freed from captivation at the end of the harpy's turn.

Critical Failure As failure, but if attacked by the harpy, the creature can attempt a new save at the start of its next turn, rather than being freed at the end of the harpy's turn.
NQF0fD75864Ytav1.name: Captivating Song

g2SVVtNILSvWr6mT.description:
Effect The harpy forager emits a shrill screech. Each non-harpy creature within a @Template[burst|distance:30] must attempt a @Check[fortitude|dc:24] save. Once a creature succeeds at any save against Disorienting Shriek, that creature is temporarily immune to Disorienting Shrieks for 24 hours.

Critical Success The creature is unaffected.

Success The creature is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.i3OJZU2nk64Df3xm]{Clumsy 1} for 1 round.

Failure The creature is clumsy 1 for 1 minute.

Critical Failure The creature is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.i3OJZU2nk64Df3xm]{Clumsy 2} for 1 minute.
g2SVVtNILSvWr6mT.name: Disorienting Shriek

Harpy Forager.name: Harpy Forager

mkJJ2xIJiTP1TKEI.description: The harpy wailer unleashes blast of sound that deals @Damage[10d6[sonic]] damage in a @Template[line|distance:60] (@Check[reflex|dc:27|basic]). She can't use Sonic Screech again for [[/gmr 1d4 #Recharge Sonic Screech]]{1d4 rounds}.
mkJJ2xIJiTP1TKEI.name: Sonic Screech

Harpy Wailer.name: Harpy Wailer

Hidden Forest Bog.description: A 15-foot wide area of verdant-covered water attempts to suck creatures down into it.
Hidden Forest Bog.hazardDisable: Two @Check[survival|dc:18] (trained) checks to find roots and tree limbs sturdy enough for everyone to use as escape paths ends the hazard's threat to all creatures in the area
Hidden Forest Bog.hazardReset: The hazard still submerges anyone who walks in, but the surface doesn't become hidden again until it accumulates leaf and greenery cover over the course of 24 hours.
Hidden Forest Bog.hazardRoutine:
(one action) On its initiative, the bog pulls down each creature within it. A creature that was submerged to its waist becomes submerged to its neck, and a creature that was submerged up to its neck is pulled under and must hold its breath to avoid suffocation.

A creature partially or fully submerged in the bog can attempt a @Check[athletics|dc:16|traits:action:swim] check to Swim to either raise itself by one step (pulled under to submerged to its neck, or submerged to its neck to submerged to its waist), or to escape from the bog if it's submerged only up to its waist. This DC increases to @Check[athletics|dc:18|traits:action:swim] for creatures submerged up to their neck or worse. On a critical failure, the creature is pulled down one step. Other creatures can @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.HCl3pzVefiv9ZKQW]{Aid}, typically by using a rope or similar assistance (providing an automatic success), or attempt to pull a single affected creature out with their own Athletics check, with the same results as if the aiding creature attempted the check itself.
Hidden Forest Bog.name: Hidden Forest Bog

House Spirits With a Large Number of Reg.description: A group of house spirits run around the lunchroom hurling pies at the walls and all the people in the room—and then the pies magically reconstitute and throw themselves again.
House Spirits With a Large Number of Reg.hazardDisable: @Check[diplomacy|dc:20], @Check[deception|dc:20], or @Check[intimidation|dc:20] four times to convince the spirits to undo their spells, @Check[arcana|dc:18] or @Check[occultism|dc:21] to unravel a pie's enchantments, or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.9HpwDN4MYQJnW0LG]{Dispel Magic} (2nd rank; counteract DC 18) to undo one pies' worth of spells. Three successes are required to disable the hazard.
House Spirits With a Large Number of Reg.hazardRoutine: (3 actions) The hazard regenerates any pies that it has thrown at a cost of one action per pie (to a maximum of 3 active pies). Each successful check to disable the hazard deactivates one of the pies, reducing the number of active pies by 1. After regenerating pies on its turn, the hazard throws pies whenever a creature triggers continually sur-piesed. For each pie Strike, roll [[/r 1d4]]. On a 1, the pie pan has nails driven into it by Numblekin and deals an additional @Damage[(1d10+6)[piercing]] damage. The nails make the pie's damage lethal, rather than nonlethal.
House Spirits With a Large Number of Reg.name: House Spirits With a Large Number of Regenerating Pies

House Spirits With an Absurd Number of R.description: A group of house spirits run around the lunchroom hurling pies at the walls and all the people in the room—and then the pies magically reconstitute and throw themselves again.
House Spirits With an Absurd Number of R.hazardDisable: @Check[diplomacy|dc:23], @Check[deception|dc:23], or @Check[intimidation|dc:23] four times to convince the spirits to undo their spells, @Check[arcana|dc:21] or @Check[occultism|dc:21] to unravel a pie's enchantments, or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.9HpwDN4MYQJnW0LG]{Dispel Magic} (2nd rank; counteract DC 18) to undo one pies' worth of spells. Three successes are required to disable the hazard.
House Spirits With an Absurd Number of R.hazardRoutine: (4 actions) The hazard regenerates any pies that it has thrown at a cost of one action per pie (to a maximum of 4 active pies). Each successful check to disable the hazard deactivates one of the pies, reducing the number of active pies by 1. After regenerating pies on its turn, the hazard throws pies whenever a creature triggers continually sur-piesed. For each pie Strike, roll [[/r 1d4]]. On a 1, the pie pan has nails driven into it by Numblekin and deals an additional @Damage[(2d8+7)[piercing]] damage. The nails make the pie's damage lethal, rather than nonlethal.
House Spirits With an Absurd Number of R.name: House Spirits With an Absurd Number of Regenerating Pies

In The Witch's Clutches.description: Spectral hag claws reach out from the walls of the gem-like chamber to grab the PCs' souls and pull them into the trap's onyx facets.
In The Witch's Clutches.hazardDisable: @Check[thievery|dc:28] (expert) or @Check[crafting|dc:28](expert) to find the weak spot and crack each facet, or dispel magic (5th level; counteract DC 26) to counteract each facet; the hazard has a number of facets equal to the number of PCs.
In The Witch's Clutches.hazardRoutine:
The hazard gains a number of actions equal to the number of PCs; it loses 1 action each round for each facet that has been disabled. Each claw tears at a different PC, who takes @Damage[(2d10+13)[mental]]{2d10 + 13 mental damage} (basic @Check[will|dc:30] save). On a failure, they are @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.kWc1fhmv9LBiTuei]{Grabbed} by the claw (@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.SkZAQRkLLkmBQNB9]{Escape} DC 28). On a critical failure, or on a failure if they are already grabbed, they have their soul ripped from their body, which falls @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.fBnFDH2MTzgFijKf]{Unconscious}. Each round on their turn, the soul can attempt a @Check[intimidation|dc:28], @Check[occultism|dc:28], or @Check[survival|dc:28] check to fortify itself and return to its body as a three-action activity. The possible outcomes are as follows.

Critical Success The soul returns to their body, which loses the unconscious condition.

Success The soul returns to their body, which loses the unconscious condition, but gains the grabbed condition.

Failure The soul makes no progress toward escape.

Critical Failure The soul makes no progress toward escape and the target takes @Damage[(2d10+13)[mental]]{2d10 + 13 mental damage} until they are reduced to 0 Hit Points, after which they remain in captivity until the trap is defeated.

Each claw focuses on its target until the target is reduced to 0 Hit Points, after which it takes no action on its turn unless another facet is disabled or its target regains Hit Points.
In The Witch's Clutches.name: In The Witch's Clutches

Each claw focuses on its target until the target is reduced to 0 Hit Points, after which it takes no action on its turn unless another facet is disabled or its target regains Hit Points.

S804GvKh0CKfjBk5.description: The infested clockwork heap unleashes a cloud of loosely connected debris that whirls around its body at incredible speed. Each creature within @Template[burst|distance:30]{30 feet} takes @Damage[2d10[bludgeoning]] damage (@Check[fortitude|dc:22|basic]).
S804GvKh0CKfjBk5.name: Scrap Tempest

cVNNBjTmEEyKPfsI.description:
Requirements The infested clockwork heap's last action was a success with an infested touch Strike

Effect A fragment of the infesting spirit attaches to the target's clothing or armor, making the creature encumbered. The encumbered condition from Overburden disappears when the infested clockwork is destroyed or after 10 minutes, whichever comes first.
cVNNBjTmEEyKPfsI.name: Overburden

Infested Clockwork Vessel.description:
Intricate, complex machines, clockworks are built with care by highly skilled engineers. Though their creation involves some amount of magic, they're primarily mechanical, packed with precision-tuned gears and springs working in concert.

The sturdy mainspring within a clockwork must be wound to provide the energy needed to power the device. Some larger clockworks contain a series of springs for different limbs that each need to be wound. A clockwork's crafter creates a unique metal key while building the clockwork; winding the clockwork usually involves inserting the key into the machine's back and turning clockwise. Larger clockworks require greater strength to turn the key, and typically have larger keys to allow for more torque-some even accommodating a team of winders rather than an individual. Programming a clockwork requires both the key and the knowledge to set the program correctly, information usually reserved for the clockwork's creator or owner.

BaTacjtQvnaLoVc5.description:
24 hours, @Check[thievery|traits:action:disable-a-device|dc:23], standby

For a clockwork to act, it must be wound with a unique key by another creature. This takes 1 minute. Once wound, it remains operational for the listed amount of time, usually 24 hours, after which time it becomes unaware of its surroundings and can't act until it's wound again. Some clockworks' abilities require them to spend some of their remaining operational time. They can't spend more than they have and shut down immediately once they have 0 time remaining. If it's unclear when a clockwork was last wound, most clockwork keepers wind all their clockworks at a set time, typically 8 a.m.

A clockwork that lists standby in its wind-up entry can enter standby mode as a 3-action activity. Its operational time doesn't decrease in standby, but it can sense its surroundings (with a -2 penalty to Perception). It can't act, with one exception: when it perceives a creature, it can exit standby as a reaction (rolling initiative if appropriate).

A creature can attempt to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.cYdz2grcOcRt4jk6]{Disable a Device} to wind a clockwork down (with a DC listed in the wind-up entry). For each success, the clockwork loses 1 hour of operational time. This can be done even if the clockwork is in standby mode.
BaTacjtQvnaLoVc5.name: Wind-Up

ZtBGSitn2S3exhut.description: The controlled clockwork vessel releases arcs of void energy from the essence-gatherer on its back. Creatures within a @Template[emanation|distance:10] take @Damage[9d6[void]|options:area-damage] damage (@Check[fortitude|dc:23|basic|options:area-effect]). The vessel can't use Etheric Discharge for [[/gmr 1d4 #Recharge Etheric Discharge]]{1d4 rounds}.
ZtBGSitn2S3exhut.name: Etheric Discharge

jZf3j2xK5YKD3uC0.description:
One of the soldier's external plates extends on a mechanical actuator to defend the soldier or an adjacent creature of the soldier's choice.

The creature gains a +2 circumstance bonus to AC until the start of the soldier's next turn, or until it is no longer adjacent to the soldier, whichever comes first. The soldier can have no more than one plate extended at a time.

@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-effects.Item.ya8r3IdzQ7QGNH8N]{Effect: Activate Defenses}
jZf3j2xK5YKD3uC0.name: Activate Defenses

Infested Clockwork Vessel.name: Infested Clockwork Vessel

It Pours.description: Water splashes within an ornate 5-foot-tall amphora. The glossy exterior depicts images of a marid trapped in a cage of flames, the frightened creature waving their hands in warning.
It Pours.hazardDisable: @Check[thievery|dc:26] (trained) to scrape the flames away from the marid's image (requires two successes); @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.9HpwDN4MYQJnW0LG]{Dispel Magic} (3rd rank; counteract DC 25) to disrupt the magical prison, disabling the trap for 10 minutes; or touch the amphora with Rayyan's seal to free the marid
It Pours.hazardReset: The trap deactivates and resets if 2 minutes pass without a creature inside the room.
It Pours.hazardRoutine: (1 action) The trap has one action per round by default, though it may gain more actions based on the encounter's scaling as listed in the sidebar. On each of the trap's actions, the amphora pours out water, increasing the depth of the water by 5 feet. Once the room is full of water, creatures in the room begin drowning, and the trap deals @Damage[(2d10+9)[bludgeoning]] damage with a @Check[fortitude|dc:25|basic] save to each creature in the room on its action as the water pressure increases.
It Pours.name: It Pours

It Rains.description: Water splashes within an ornate 5-foot-tall amphora. The glossy exterior depicts images of a marid trapped in a cage of flames, the frightened creature waving their hands in warning.
It Rains.hazardDisable: @Check[thievery|dc:24] (trained) to scrape the flames away from the marid's image (requires two successes); @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.9HpwDN4MYQJnW0LG]{Dispel Magic} (2nd rank; counteract DC 23) to disrupt the magical prison, disabling the trap for 10 minutes; or touch the amphora with Rayyan's seal to free the marid
It Rains.hazardReset: The trap deactivates and resets if 2 minutes pass without a creature inside the room.
It Rains.hazardRoutine: (1 action) The trap has one action per round by default, though it may gain more actions based on the encounter's scaling as listed in the sidebar. On each of the trap's actions, the amphora pours out water, increasing the depth of the water by 5 feet. Once the room is full of water, creatures in the room begin drowning, and the trap deals @Damage[(2d8+7)[bludgeoning]] damage with a @Check[fortitude|dc:22|basic] save to each creature in the room on its action as the water pressure increases.
It Rains.name: It Rains

3wZ70T5je0FiECFv.description: You shroud a creature or object in wards that hide its alignment. The target appears to be neutral to all effects that would detect its alignment.
3wZ70T5je0FiECFv.name: Undetectable Alignment

MP56QOH507crCZp4.description:
A small ball of flame appears in the palm of your hand, and you lash out with it either in melee or at range. Make a spell attack roll against your target's AC. This is normally a ranged attack, but you can also make a melee attack against a creature in your unarmed reach.

On a success, you deal 2d4 fire damage. On a critical success, the target takes double damage and @Damage[(@item.level)d4[persistent,fire]] damage.

Heightened (+1) Increase the damage by 1d4 and the persistent damage on a critical hit by 1d4.
MP56QOH507crCZp4.name: Produce Flame

dKMiHZW7UIjT2STV.description:
When Larcuis casts a bloodline spell, @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.IihxWhRfpsBgQ5jS]{Enthrall}, @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.2ZdHjnpEQJuqOYSG]{Floating Flame}, or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.vLA0q0WOK2YPuJs6]{Charm}, either a target takes 1 fire damage per spell rank, or he gains a +1 status bonus to Deception checks for 1 round.

@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-effects.Item.tvybMInVm415jA3p]{Effect: Bloodline Magic (+1 deception)}
dKMiHZW7UIjT2STV.name: Bloodline Magic

mTfM1psyGA4AWIKx.description: When Larcuis Casts a Spell from a spell slot, if the spell deals damage and doesn't have a duration, he gains a status bonus equal to the spell's rank to that spell's damage.
mTfM1psyGA4AWIKx.name: Dangerous Sorcery

nYkxfw9X0fF50mX2.description: Providing the same defensive function as a standard gauntlet, this version has a group of spikes protruding from the knuckles to deliver piercing damage with a punch.

q9KNJhfPdbxTgrHT.description: A healing potion is a vial of a ruby-red liquid that imparts a tingling sensation as the drinker's wounds heal rapidly. When you drink a healing potion, you regain @Damage[1d8[healing]] Hit Points.

z6DtiKop8mk5Ngxj.description:
Activate 1 Interact

After you drink this elixir, your sight becomes sharper in darkness. You gain darkvision for 10 minutes.

@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.equipment-effects.Item.7UL8belWmo7U5YGM]{Effect: Darkvision Elixir (Lesser)}

6Y0iLMv0EtEg3lSN.description:
This disease's condition ends after 1 hour

Saving Throw @Check[fortitude|dc:13]

Stage 1 @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.i3OJZU2nk64Df3xm]{Clumsy 1} (1 round)

Stage 2 clumsy 1 (1 hour)
6Y0iLMv0EtEg3lSN.name: Itchy Rash

ZzqnOy2oIOko1Izc.description: The lemming rat Strides or Climbs a total of three times, then becomes @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.AJh5ex99aV6VTggg]{Off-Guard} until the start of its next turn.
ZzqnOy2oIOko1Izc.name: Hurried Skitter

eXYpsUa9HYwNt3nN.description:
Trigger The lemming rat is falling

Effect The lemming rat spreads its limbs, allowing flaps of skin between its limbs and abdomen to arrest its fall. The lemming rat's fall slows to 60 feet per round and it can move horizontally 5 feet for every 10 feet it falls. If it ends its movement adjacent to a creature, it can attempt a jaws Strike on that creature with a +2 circumstance bonus to its attack roll.
eXYpsUa9HYwNt3nN.name: Death Glide

7t0hoAr4rbWswzMK.description:
Frequency once per day

Trigger Liaskra is hit with an unarmed Strike or a Strike with a non-reach melee weapon

Effect Liaskra breaks off quills in her attacker's flesh. She deals @Damage[1d8[piercing]] damage to the triggering creature (@Check[reflex|dc:17|basic]). On a critical failure, the creature also takes @Damage[1d4[bleed]] damage as the quills hook into their flesh.
7t0hoAr4rbWswzMK.name: Barbed Quills

LHV1Y69RCdChvRwx.description: Liaskra musters her guile to attempt a clever attack that catches her foe unprepared. Liaskra chooses one of her weapons. The next attack with that weapon deals an extra 1d6 precision damage. In addition, Liaskra can Interact to draw the weapon (or to reload it if she chooses the hand crossbow).
LHV1Y69RCdChvRwx.name: Trick Attack

7t0hoAr4rbWswzMK.description:
Frequency once per day

Trigger Liaskra is hit with an unarmed Strike or a Strike with a non-reach melee weapon

Effect Liaskra breaks off quills in her attacker's flesh. She deals @Damage[2d8[piercing]] damage to the triggering creature (@Check[reflex|dc:21|basic]). On a critical failure, the creature also takes @Damage[(1d4+1)[bleed]] damage as the quills hook into their flesh.
7t0hoAr4rbWswzMK.name: Barbed Quills

LHV1Y69RCdChvRwx.description: Liaskra musters her guile to attempt a clever attack that catches her foe unprepared. Liaskra chooses one of her weapons. The next attack with that weapon deals an extra 2d6 precision damage. In addition, Liaskra can Interact to draw the weapon (or to reload it if she chooses the hand crossbow).
LHV1Y69RCdChvRwx.name: Trick Attack

Living Boulder (PFS 4-04).description: Living boulders roll and glide through the Plane of Earth, gathering gemstones and metal shards until their surfaces resemble a ship's hull covered in barnacles. Barely more intelligent than many animals, living boulders fill much the same role on the Plane of Earth as the great herd animals found on Material Plane worlds.

1fTRsJAGDuFgPeXF.description: A living boulder can @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.H6v1VgowHaKHnVlG]{Burrow} through earthen matter, including rock. When it does so, it moves at its full burrow Speed, leaving no tunnels or signs of its passing.
1fTRsJAGDuFgPeXF.name: Earth Glide

MJIrkULpmp4soA0F.description: The living boulder Strides twice, and can then make a Strike with its jaws. This jaws Strike gains @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-ability-glossary-srd.Item.BCLvAx4Pz4MLa2pu]{Knockdown}.
MJIrkULpmp4soA0F.name: Rolling Charge

Living Boulder (PFS 4-04).name: Living Boulder (PFS 4-04)

Major Fireball Rune.description: An invisible rune creates an invisible, spherical magical sensor with a 20-foot radius.
Major Fireball Rune.hazardDisable: @Check[thievery|dc:28] (expert) to erase the rune without triggering the sensor, or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.9HpwDN4MYQJnW0LG]{Dispel Magic} (5th rank; counteract DC 26) to counteract the rune
Major Fireball Rune.name: Major Fireball Rune

Malevolent Reflections.description: Ornate full-length mirrors with fiendish filigree depict the image of Fasiel ibn Sazadin in villainous triumph over his enemies.
Malevolent Reflections.hazardDisable: @Check[stealth|dc:27] (trained) to approach a mirror without showing up in the reflection, followed by @Check[thievery|dc:25] to cover mirror or dispel magic (3nd level; counteract DC 25) to counteract the binding
Malevolent Reflections.name: Malevolent Reflections

Meddlesome Scrit.description:
Scrits are short, spindly gremlins with gray or beige leathery skin and a coat of smeared ink on their fingers. They make themselves the nightmare of many scribes and librarians, as they delight in nothing more than destroying books, scrolls, artwork, and other records or writing. The oils on a scrit's skin smears ink and renders text-even magical writing-completely illegible. Once they have smeared every page of a book, scrits devour them whole, absorbing the contents the book used to hold. After eating books they find stupid or funny, scrits hold skits for other gremlins which mock the mortal authors for the amusement of the other fey.

Gremlins are malicious fey that infest and prey upon mortal communities. They live in tunnels, beneath eaves, and in abandoned buildings, stealing what they need from their neighbors instead of creating for themselves.

While there are gremlins of any and every gender, their appearances don't differ by gender. Young gremlins grow to maturity with alarming speed. Their entire nest raises them communally, though they are often encouraged to wander unsupervised and create mischief away from home instead of inside it.

48Y9uY1twqYCaXUZ.description: The scrit rubs its fingers against one page of writing, smearing the text and rendering it unreadable. The scrit can smear and destroy magical writing such as a @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.o0l57UfBm9ScEUMW]{Rune Trap} or a @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.AUctDF2fqPZN2w4W]{Sigil} by succeeding at a counteract check (using the scrit's [[/r 1d20+8]]{spell attack modifier}) against the caster's DC.
48Y9uY1twqYCaXUZ.name: Smear Text

a0Y3uV615pfpXjsl.description:
A scrit's fingers are perpetually covered in smeared ink from the writing it's destroyed. This ink mixes with its skin oils to create a disgusting, sticky poison.

Saving Throw @Check[fortitude|dc:14]

Maximum Duration 4 rounds

Stage 1 @Damage[1d4[poison]] damage and @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 1} (1 round)
a0Y3uV615pfpXjsl.name: Nasty Ink

Meddlesome Scrit.name: Meddlesome Scrit

Menacing Shadow Drake.description: Shadow drakes are typically among the smallest and least powerful of their species. Most stand as tall and long as house cats and have charcoal-colored scales and membranous wings just translucent enough to pass for shadows. Attracted to shiny materials, they employ deception, teamwork, and even rudimentary traps to create opportunities to make off with ill-gotten gains. Shadow drakes have a particular fascination and admiration for umbral dragons-a notable exception to the norm for drakes and dragons.

0VNX7MbrCqRSKYkE.description:
Trigger A creature attacks the shadow drake while it is in an area of dim light

Effect The shadow drake further obscures its position. The attacker must succeed at a @Check[flat|dc:11] check in order to affect the shadow drake, as if the drake were @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.iU0fEDdBp3rXpTMC]{Hidden} for the triggering attack.
0VNX7MbrCqRSKYkE.name: Shadow Evade

5IixHzakyftZgS0g.description:
Frequency three times per day

Effect The shadow drake Strides or Flies twice.
5IixHzakyftZgS0g.name: Speed Surge

QNy9Hrx2ib5tkQKt.description: The shadow drake's form shifts and blends reflexively with surrounding shadows. A shadow drake gains an additional reaction each round, but it can use this reaction only for Shadow Evade.
QNy9Hrx2ib5tkQKt.name: Shadow Blend

usIKpszaYrCWfN8r.description:
A shadow drake spits a ball of black liquid that explodes into a cloud of frigid black shadow. This attack has a range of 40 feet and explodes in a 5-foot-radius burst. Creatures within the burst take @Damage[3d6[cold]] damage (@Check[reflex|dc:18|basic] save). The explosion of shadow also snuffs out mundane light sources the size of a torch, lantern, or smaller, and attempts to counteract magical light with a +10 counteract modifier.

The shadow drake can't use Shadow Breath again for [[/r 1d6]] rounds.
usIKpszaYrCWfN8r.name: Shadow Breath

wnZi8QCOMG86Db4l.description: The shadow drake makes one bite Strike and two tail Strikes in any order.
wnZi8QCOMG86Db4l.name: Draconic Frenzy

Menacing Shadow Drake.name: Menacing Shadow Drake

Mutated Scorpion.description:
These massive, terrifying arachnids are typically 8 feet long from head to the base of the tail. Giant scorpions are the favored pack animals and war beasts of various desert-dwelling monsters, particularly gnolls. They are most commonly encountered in the wild, however. There they lair in mountainside caves or burrow beneath shallow layers of sand where they lie in wait for prey to wander near. Sleek, pallid subterranean scorpions also exist, as do still larger species.

Chitinous scourges of deserts, forests, savannas, and badlands, scorpions are deadly arachnids with powerful pincers and a painful sting. Scorpions can be found in nearly every climate, where they hunt their prey with a mixture of patient stealth and raw strength. Most scorpions live in underground burrows, either as lone hunters or part of a larger colony. These arachnids are so feared and dangerous that in many cultures, they are treated as deities or dualistic symbols of both death and protection from said death.

WuUxcHe2LEnb3BVQ.description:
Saving Throw @Check[fortitude|dc:20]

Maximum Duration 6 rounds

Stage 1 @Damage[3d6[poison]] damage and @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.MIRkyAjyBeXivMa7]{Enfeebled 1} (1 round)

Stage 2 @Damage[4d6[poison]] damage and enfeebled 1 (1 round)

Stage 3 4d6 poison damage and @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.MIRkyAjyBeXivMa7]{Enfeebled 2} (1 round)
WuUxcHe2LEnb3BVQ.name: Giant Scorpion Venom

Mutated Scorpion.name: Mutated Scorpion

F44pNDrMtxw9rISh.description: Nathatel channels a spell into a melee attack to deliver a magically charged attack. He Casts a Spell that takes 1 or 2 actions to cast and requires a spell attack roll. The effects of the spell don't occur immediately but are imbued into his attack instead. He makes a melee Strike with a weapon or unarmed attack, which gains the arcane trait. His spell is coupled with the attack, using his attack roll to determine the effects of both the Strike and the spell. This counts as two attacks for his multiple attack penalty, but the penalty isn't applied until after he has completed the Spellstrike. After he uses Spellstrike, Nathatel can't do so again until he recharges this ability as a single action, which has the concentrate trait. He also recharges his Spellstrike when he casts @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.9mPEoOPN0AMuixIv]{Force Fang} or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.r82rqcm0MmGaBFkM]{Thunderous Strike}.
F44pNDrMtxw9rISh.name: Spellstrike

Trigger Nathatel succeeds at a save against a foe's harmful spell, or a foe fails a spell attack roll against him

Effect Nathatel redirects the spell's energy back at its caster. The caster takes @Damage[1d6[bludgeoning]] damage per spell rank (@Check[reflex|dc:23] negates). If the harmful spell dealt damage of a particular type, such fire damage, use that type instead of bludgeoning.
Kl55zvqSZlU2vmN7.name: Redirect Magic

HbVNA1Ibe1obOwtL.description: Vrisk is affected by the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.4gBIw4IDrSfFHik4]{Daze} spell as if he was a living creature
HbVNA1Ibe1obOwtL.name: Vulnerable to Daze

IrJCzZfE66Y6S88d.description:
Harmed by void (@Damage[2d8[untyped]], @Damage[1d8[untyped]] from areas or persistent damage); healed by vitality (area @Damage[1d6[healing]] HP); slowed by emotion

@Localize[PF2E.NPC.Abilities.Glossary.GolemAntimagic]
IrJCzZfE66Y6S88d.name: Golem Antimagic

jxmONdR97WrExGJ9.description: Vrisk's smooth head does not have ears, so he's @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.9PR9y0bi4JPKnHPR]{Deaf}. He automatically critically fails any Perception checks that require hearing and is immune to auditory effects. He can supply verbal components for casting spells and command components for activating magic items, but if he performs an action he isn't accustomed to that involves auditory elements, he must succeed at a @Check[flat|dc:5] or the action is lost. He has both the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.feats-srd.Item.aAoFc10cOpxGypOY]{Sign Language} and @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.feats-srd.Item.yUuU9xyotrpwpTyC]{Read Lips} skill feats.
jxmONdR97WrExGJ9.name: Unfinished

xVhkhzcrxHeGPBV8.description: If targeted by @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.ifXNOhtmU4fKL68v]{Redact} or any other spell that erases text, Vrisk must succeed at a @Check[will|dc:18] save or immediately die as the rune on his forehead is erased.
xVhkhzcrxHeGPBV8.name: Vulnerable to Redact

Pappy Draighean.description:
Leprechauns are mostly jovial tricksters who prefer mischief over conflict. They fill their days with as much fun, wine, and food as possible. Mostly found in forested regions, leprechauns respect nature and those who protect it.

Leprechauns do not attack on sight. Rather, they engage in conversation and try to charm, cajole, or trick those they meet into doing favors for them or freely giving over a treasured item, usually in return for illusory wealth or false promises of wealth and success. These small tricksters are masters at discerning the desires of those they meet-a knack that puts them in a powerful position when bargaining for goods or favors. They aren't above turning people against each other for their own benefit but generally not to an extent that causes harm.

In most cases, a leprechaun doesn't keep a purloined possession for long. The leprechaun most often returns such stolen prizes just in time to defuse tensions, often as they point out the humor of the situation, hoping to share their amusement and mirth with the victim. In cases where a leprechaun's trick goes too far and results in an incensed victim, the leprechaun quickly flees the conflict rather than engage in combat. This willingness to return stolen goods or to flee from battles fades as leprechauns grow older. Ancient leprechauns who have lived for thousands of years often spiral into dark bitterness and increasingly use their powers and illusions to lure those who offend them or fail to appreciate a joke into danger... or even death.

gsSCKgcp2ueqH7pG.description: You create up to four floating lights, no two of which are more than 10 feet apart. Each sheds light like a torch. When you Sustain the Spell, you can move any number of lights up to 60 feet. Each light must remain within 120 feet of you and within 10 feet of all others, or it winks out.
gsSCKgcp2ueqH7pG.name: Dancing Lights

ixXRVHF3jg0IMuKw.description: When a leprechaun uses their innate spells to deceive, trick, or humiliate a creature, the spell DC increases to 22 and the attack modifier to +13.
ixXRVHF3jg0IMuKw.name: Leprechaun Magic

qZaBb2z6mE2zLL2u.description:
Frequency three times per day

Effect The leprechaun produces an item out of their hat, from behind their jacket, from within a hole in a tree stump, or from any other unexpected location. This conjured item must be no more than 1 Bulk and must be made of relatively commonplace material (such as cloth, wood, stone, or even low-value metal like iron or lead). It can't rely on intricate artistry or complex moving parts, never fulfills a Cost or the like, and can't be made of precious materials or materials with a rarity of uncommon or higher.

The created object is temporary and lasts for 1 hour or until the leprechaun creates a new item, whichever comes first.
qZaBb2z6mE2zLL2u.name: Create Object

Pappy Draighean.name: Pappy Draighean

Pappy Draighean (5-6).description:
Leprechauns are mostly jovial tricksters who prefer mischief over conflict. They fill their days with as much fun, wine, and food as possible. Mostly found in forested regions, leprechauns respect nature and those who protect it.

Leprechauns do not attack on sight. Rather, they engage in conversation and try to charm, cajole, or trick those they meet into doing favors for them or freely giving over a treasured item, usually in return for illusory wealth or false promises of wealth and success. These small tricksters are masters at discerning the desires of those they meet-a knack that puts them in a powerful position when bargaining for goods or favors. They aren't above turning people against each other for their own benefit but generally not to an extent that causes harm.

In most cases, a leprechaun doesn't keep a purloined possession for long. The leprechaun most often returns such stolen prizes just in time to defuse tensions, often as they point out the humor of the situation, hoping to share their amusement and mirth with the victim. In cases where a leprechaun's trick goes too far and results in an incensed victim, the leprechaun quickly flees the conflict rather than engage in combat. This willingness to return stolen goods or to flee from battles fades as leprechauns grow older. Ancient leprechauns who have lived for thousands of years often spiral into dark bitterness and increasingly use their powers and illusions to lure those who offend them or fail to appreciate a joke into danger... or even death.

gsSCKgcp2ueqH7pG.description: You create up to four floating lights, no two of which are more than 10 feet apart. Each sheds light like a torch. When you Sustain the Spell, you can move any number of lights up to 60 feet. Each light must remain within 120 feet of you and within 10 feet of all others, or it winks out.
gsSCKgcp2ueqH7pG.name: Dancing Lights

ixXRVHF3jg0IMuKw.description: When a leprechaun uses their innate spells to deceive, trick, or humiliate a creature, the spell DC increases to 24 and the attack modifier to +15.
ixXRVHF3jg0IMuKw.name: Leprechaun Magic

qZaBb2z6mE2zLL2u.description:
Frequency three times per day

Effect The leprechaun produces an item out of their hat, from behind their jacket, from within a hole in a tree stump, or from any other unexpected location. This conjured item must be no more than 1 Bulk and must be made of relatively commonplace material (such as cloth, wood, stone, or even low-value metal like iron or lead). It can't rely on intricate artistry or complex moving parts, never fulfills a Cost or the like, and can't be made of precious materials or materials with a rarity of uncommon or higher.

The created object is temporary and lasts for 1 hour or until the leprechaun creates a new item, whichever comes first.
qZaBb2z6mE2zLL2u.name: Create Object

Pappy Draighean (5-6).name: Pappy Draighean (5-6)

SIlsfeJHorbIUO9o.description: When a crumbling automaton hits a creature with their barbed net, the net wraps around the target, which becomes @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.i3OJZU2nk64Df3xm]{Clumsy 1} and takes a -10-foot circumstance penalty to its Speeds. If the Strike was a critical success, the target is also @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.eIcWbB5o3pP6OIMe]{Immobilized}. When a creature Escapes (DC 20), or if the Strike misses, the net crumbles into nothing. Each time a creature attempts to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.SkZAQRkLLkmBQNB9]{Escape}, it takes @Damage[1d8[slashing]] damage from the net's barbs, regardless of whether the attempt succeeds.
SIlsfeJHorbIUO9o.name: Barbed Net

S804GvKh0CKfjBk5.description: The infested clockwork heap unleashes a cloud of loosely connected debris that whirls around its body at incredible speed. Each creature within @Template[burst|distance:30]{30 feet} takes @Damage[3d8[bludgeoning]] damage (@Check[fortitude|dc:25|basic]).
S804GvKh0CKfjBk5.name: Scrap Tempest

cVNNBjTmEEyKPfsI.description:
Requirements The infested clockwork heap's last action was a success with an infested touch Strike

Effect A fragment of the infesting spirit attaches to the target's clothing or armor, making the creature encumbered. The encumbered condition from Overburden disappears when the infested clockwork is destroyed or after 10 minutes, whichever comes first.
cVNNBjTmEEyKPfsI.name: Overburden

Possessed Clockwork Vessel.description:
Intricate, complex machines, clockworks are built with care by highly skilled engineers. Though their creation involves some amount of magic, they're primarily mechanical, packed with precision-tuned gears and springs working in concert.

The sturdy mainspring within a clockwork must be wound to provide the energy needed to power the device. Some larger clockworks contain a series of springs for different limbs that each need to be wound. A clockwork's crafter creates a unique metal key while building the clockwork; winding the clockwork usually involves inserting the key into the machine's back and turning clockwise. Larger clockworks require greater strength to turn the key, and typically have larger keys to allow for more torque-some even accommodating a team of winders rather than an individual. Programming a clockwork requires both the key and the knowledge to set the program correctly, information usually reserved for the clockwork's creator or owner.

BaTacjtQvnaLoVc5.description:
24 hours, @Check[thievery|traits:action:disable-a-device|dc:26], standby

For a clockwork to act, it must be wound with a unique key by another creature. This takes 1 minute. Once wound, it remains operational for the listed amount of time, usually 24 hours, after which time it becomes unaware of its surroundings and can't act until it's wound again. Some clockworks' abilities require them to spend some of their remaining operational time. They can't spend more than they have and shut down immediately once they have 0 time remaining. If it's unclear when a clockwork was last wound, most clockwork keepers wind all their clockworks at a set time, typically 8 a.m.

A clockwork that lists standby in its wind-up entry can enter standby mode as a 3-action activity. Its operational time doesn't decrease in standby, but it can sense its surroundings (with a -2 penalty to Perception). It can't act, with one exception: when it perceives a creature, it can exit standby as a reaction (rolling initiative if appropriate).

A creature can attempt to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.cYdz2grcOcRt4jk6]{Disable a Device} to wind a clockwork down (with a DC listed in the wind-up entry). For each success, the clockwork loses 1 hour of operational time. This can be done even if the clockwork is in standby mode.
BaTacjtQvnaLoVc5.name: Wind-Up

ZtBGSitn2S3exhut.description: The controlled clockwork vessel releases arcs of void energy from the essence-gatherer on its back. Creatures within a @Template[emanation|distance:10] take @Damage[11d6[void]|options:area-damage] damage (@Check[fortitude|dc:26|basic|options:area-effect]). The vessel can't use Etheric Discharge for [[/gmr 1d4 #Recharge Etheric Discharge]]{1d4 rounds}.
ZtBGSitn2S3exhut.name: Etheric Discharge

jZf3j2xK5YKD3uC0.description:
One of the soldier's external plates extends on a mechanical actuator to defend the soldier or an adjacent creature of the soldier's choice.

The creature gains a +2 circumstance bonus to AC until the start of the soldier's next turn, or until it is no longer adjacent to the soldier, whichever comes first. The soldier can have no more than one plate extended at a time.

@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-effects.Item.ya8r3IdzQ7QGNH8N]{Effect: Activate Defenses}
jZf3j2xK5YKD3uC0.name: Activate Defenses

Possessed Clockwork Vessel.name: Possessed Clockwork Vessel

2RwCLa2X9KcE2AZT.description:
Requirements The etheroot's last action was a success with a Strike using its stalked bite.

Effect Wounds caused by the potted violet etheroot's stalked bite can create an intense emotional response. The creature damaged by the etheroot's stalked bite is subjected to an effect of the etheroot's choice from the following (@Check[will|dc:22] save; duration 1 minute unless otherwise stated):

  • Despair: Target must attempt a Will save as if subjected to the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.GaRQlC9Yw1BGKHfN]{Wave of Despair} spell.
  • Fear: Target must attempt a Will save as if targeted by the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.4koZzrnMXhhosn0D]{Fear} spell.
  • Hope: Target is affected as if subjected to the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.IAjvwqgiDr3qGYxY]{Courageous Anthem} cantrip and must attempt a Will save to determine duration.

Critical Success The target is affected for 4 rounds.

Success The target is affected for 3 rounds.

Failure The target is affected for 1 round.

Critical Failure The target is unaffected.

  • Serenity: Target must attempt a Will save as if subjected to the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.b515AZlB0sridKSq]{Calm} spell.
2RwCLa2X9KcE2AZT.name: Incite Emotion

GmyoeJXVE7meQPHO.description: The potted violet etheroot makes two Strikes with two different tentacles, each limb targeting a different creature. This counts as two attacks toward the etheroot's multiple attack penalty for further actions, but the penalty doesn't increase until after both attacks are made.
GmyoeJXVE7meQPHO.name: Tentacle Flurry

MoXlRdkqmBlP99T0.description: The potted violet etheroot can sense the emotions of creatures within 120 feet as an imprecise sense. Emotion sense is a precise sense against creatures under an emotion effect. A creature under the effects of @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.b515AZlB0sridKSq]{Calm} or the serenity effect of the etheroot's Incite Emotion ability can't be noticed via emotion sense.
MoXlRdkqmBlP99T0.name: Emotion Sense

N2odnc38PRSdfd3G.description: The potted violet etheroot is rooted in a soulfired pot, which was glazed within a hellish kiln and which, like normal objects, has Hardness and grants the etheroot resistance to fire. This Hardness reduces any damage the etheroot takes by an amount equal to the Hardness. Once the potted violet etheroot is reduced to less than half its Hit Points, or immediately upon being damaged by a critical hit, its soulfired pot breaks, it loses its resistance to fire, and its AC is reduced to 23. Breaking the pot also increases the etheroot's speed to 25 feet.
N2odnc38PRSdfd3G.name: Soulfired Pot

Pups.description: Bonds of loyalty that endure beyond death reanimate pets to crawl from their graves within days of dying, returning to the side of their past owners, family, or pack. Unfortunately, death irrevocably changes a risen pet. They return as aggressive, predatory beasts, difficult to control and easy to anger. Even the most friendly and docile of pets becomes sadistic and violent in undeath—fixating first on those it views as competition for the attention of its owners. When a risen pet is jilted, rebuffed, or offended by its owner, it turns on them.

2ynj848nvp9c3igy.description: Pups' Strikes deal 1d4 additional damage to living creatures.
2ynj848nvp9c3igy.name: Betray the Living

83mbwwys64b7tvby.description: Pups knows the direction of its past owner or family (as long as they're both on the same plane), but not the distance.
83mbwwys64b7tvby.name: Sense Companion

pcv2wjgq3skfdwr1.description: 10 feet. A creature entering the aura or starting its turn in the aura must succeed at a @Check[fortitude|dc:14] save or become @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 1} (plus @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3]{Slowed 1} for as long as it's sickened on a critical failure). While within the aura, affected creatures take a -2 circumstance penalty to saves against disease and to recover from the sickened condition. A creature that succeeds at its save is temporarily immune for 1 minute.
pcv2wjgq3skfdwr1.name: Stench

Pups.name: Pups

Recon Patroller.description:
Some forests are protected by kings, others only by wild things. Laws against hunting may protect the private reserves of nobles or guard the viability of animal populations of shared forests during specific seasons. Poachers violate those laws- sometimes out of greed, sometimes out of desperation, and sometimes for sport. Although penalties against poaching often include public shaming, in lean times a successful poacher is a local hero.

From the managed and cultivated forests that support villages to the tree-covered crown lands where only nobles and their servants are permitted to hunt, forests provide. To communities, forests provide fuel, food, medicine, and raw materials, while royally protected forests provide food for the nobles' table and a source of entertainment in the form of organized hunts. Even the ancient woods untouched by mortal hand or blade provide bards with settings where legends happened and could happen again. Many find the forest depths unsettling, but others live their lives among the trees and alongside the creatures that make their homes there.

SjfWr7t0YSZQdt8c.description:
The recon patroller can use the Crafting skill to create the following snares:

  • @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.equipment-srd.Item.AFX1V0Go9DqPWBlN]{Alarm Snare}
  • @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.equipment-srd.Item.Km4lSOsyrip5q6iD]{Hampering Snare}
  • @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.equipment-srd.Item.oplQpQSTyTvHDDtq]{Marking Snare}
  • @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.equipment-srd.Item.XcD8p1o71tPohZWT]{Signaling Snare}

The recon patroller can create four snares each day without paying for the materials, using 3 Interact actions to set up each snare.
SjfWr7t0YSZQdt8c.name: Snare Crafting

mf7WGLlP4PNbRBBP.description: This armor is simply a layer of heavy, quilted cloth, but it is sometimes used because it's so inexpensive. Padded armor is easier to damage and destroy than other types of armor. Heavy armor comes with a padded armor undercoat included in its Price, though it loses the comfort trait when worn under heavy armor. You can wear just that padded armor or undercoat to sleep in, if your heavy armor is destroyed, or when otherwise not wearing the full heavy armor. This allows you to keep the armor invested and benefit from the power of any runes on the associated heavy armor, but no one else can wear your heavy armor without the padded undercoat.

q8RnxJPpBW9f5Ie5.description: While using Survival to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.49y9Ec4bDii8pcD3]{Subsist}, if the recon patroller rolls a failure or a critical failure, they get a success instead. If the recon patroller rolls a success, they can provide food for 4 additional creatures that eat about as much as a human, or 8 creatures on a critical success.
q8RnxJPpBW9f5Ie5.name: Forager

rTeH6wIQdfQpy5CH.description: The recon patroller designates a single creature they can see and hear, or one they're Tracking, as their prey. The recon patroller gains a +2 circumstance bonus to Perception checks to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.BlAOM2X92SI6HMtJ]{Seek} the prey and to Survival checks to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.EA5vuSgJfiHH7plD]{Track} the prey. The first time the recon patroller hits the designated prey in a round, they deal an additional 1d8 precision damage. The recon patroller also ignores the penalty for making ranged attacks within their second range increment. These effects last until the recon patroller uses Hunt Prey again.
rTeH6wIQdfQpy5CH.name: Hunt Prey

Recon Patroller.name: Recon Patroller

Recon Scout.description:
Some mercenaries eschew the complications of politics, oaths of service, and fealty and just get paid to hunt monsters. It's a straightforward form of mercenary service, often dangerous in the extreme, but one that can yield glory and fame.

A broad category that includes those wielding arms, spells, or even guile and cunning, mercenaries hire themselves and their expertise to those with the gold to pay for it.

InRtCxbhS6HJi1kR.description: This large battle axe is too heavy to wield with only one hand. Many greataxes incorporate two blades, and they are often "bearded", having a hook at the bottom to increase the strength of their chopping power.

ggCUTswEGOjGvjj0.description: The recon scout Strides twice and makes a melee Strike.
ggCUTswEGOjGvjj0.name: Sudden Charge

xBb6evQkhB3uYAvn.description:
Requirements The recon scout isn't @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.HL2l2VRSaQHu9lUw]{Fatigued} or raging

Effect s The recon scout gains 9 temporary Hit Points that last until the rage ends. While raging, they deal 8 additional damage with melee attacks, gain a +10-foot status bonus to their Speed, and take a –1 penalty to AC. The recon scout can't use concentrate actions except @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.BlAOM2X92SI6HMtJ]{Seek} and rage actions. The rage lasts for 1 minute, until there are no enemies the recon scout can perceive, or until the recon scout falls @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.fBnFDH2MTzgFijKf]{Unconscious}. Once the rage ends, the recon scout can't Rage again for 1 minute.

@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.feat-effects.Item.z3uyCMBddrPK5umr]{Effect: Rage}
xBb6evQkhB3uYAvn.name: Rage

Recon Scout.name: Recon Scout

bQkVsKLMpQ48ZKhO.description:
Though they come in a variety of shapes and sizes, the protection offered by wooden shields comes from the stoutness of their materials. While wooden shields are less expensive than steel shields, they break more easily.

Hardness HP BT
3 12 6

k0RsAtkhvhFKUQYb.description: Revna can Recall Knowledge on any subject with a +9 modifier.
k0RsAtkhvhFKUQYb.name: Bardic Lore

bQkVsKLMpQ48ZKhO.description:
Though they come in a variety of shapes and sizes, the protection offered by wooden shields comes from the stoutness of their materials. While wooden shields are less expensive than steel shields, they break more easily.

Hardness HP BT
3 12 6

dztjl21nbBcixfct.description: If a reaction would disrupt Revna's spellcasting action, she attempts a @Check[flat|dc:15]. If she succeeds, her action isn't disrupted.
dztjl21nbBcixfct.name: Steady Spellcasting

k0RsAtkhvhFKUQYb.description: Revna can Recall Knowledge on any subject with a +9 modifier.
k0RsAtkhvhFKUQYb.name: Bardic Lore

1EsMXmB9tTK4sElQ.description: Rhenei gains a +2 circumstance bonus to AC until the start of their next turn.
1EsMXmB9tTK4sElQ.name: Aldori Parry

X0gq5sI7Jn6ZUAZ8.description:
A small ball of flame appears in the palm of your hand, and you lash out with it either in melee or at range. Make a spell attack roll against your target's AC. This is normally a ranged attack, but you can also make a melee attack against a creature in your unarmed reach.

On a success, you deal 2d4 fire damage. On a critical success, the target takes double damage and @Damage[(@item.level)d4[persistent,fire]] damage.

Heightened (+1) Increase the damage by 1d4 and the persistent damage on a critical hit by 1d4.
X0gq5sI7Jn6ZUAZ8.name: Produce Flame (Bludgeoning, Water)

1EsMXmB9tTK4sElQ.description: Rhenei gains a +2 circumstance bonus to AC until the start of their next turn.
1EsMXmB9tTK4sElQ.name: Aldori Parry

X0gq5sI7Jn6ZUAZ8.description:
A small ball of flame appears in the palm of your hand, and you lash out with it either in melee or at range. Make a spell attack roll against your target's AC. This is normally a ranged attack, but you can also make a melee attack against a creature in your unarmed reach.

On a success, you deal 2d4 fire damage. On a critical success, the target takes double damage and @Damage[(@item.level)d4[persistent,fire]] damage.

Heightened (+1) Increase the damage by 1d4 and the persistent damage on a critical hit by 1d4.
X0gq5sI7Jn6ZUAZ8.name: Produce Flame (Bludgeoning, Water)

Runt (1-2).description:
These squat, mud-brown drakes resemble scaly pit bulls with blunt, toothy snouts. The desert drake is the prairie drake's closest known relative, as both share a strong affinity for earth, can burrow through soil, and hack up balls of dirt that they aim at enemies. But whereas a desert drake is sleek and nimble, flying through lightning storms and siroccos with ease, the prairie drake has all the grace of a chicken, barely able to flutter clumsily up a low hill or over a boulder. Owing to their largely vestigial wings, it's no wonder prairie drakes prefer burrowing over soaring.

The average prairie drake has a temperament similar to that of a wicked child who delights in tormenting others. They ambush tiny animals from underground and play with their food thoroughly before eating. To assert their supremacy over other scrubland predators, prairie drakes knock down their rivals and attack them mercilessly. They often make grisly displays from the corpses of their foes to intimidate other would-be competitors.

Prairie drakes build and live in burrow mounds just beneath the surface of their environs. They make shallow tunnels in search of large insects, rodents, and ground snakes. Prairie drakes' presence helps to turn the topsoil and encourage new plant growth, supporting other animal life and making them a keystone species for the environment. Even their breath weapon leaves behind rich "drake soil," coveted by farmers and gardeners for the potent effects it has on plants. Being seen as "useful" or "beneficial" annoys most prairie drakes, who believe such a reputation makes them look weak and conflicts with their "apex predator" mystique. After they've gotten too much positive attention, a prairie drake is apt to murder a farm animal or destroy croplands only to prove that they're far from harmless.

oC6tsYcetiZkAEEq.description: Once per day, your familiar can use 2 actions with the concentrate trait to give up some of its animating energy and heal you. It must be in your space to do so. You restore a number of Hit Points equal to @Damage[(max(floor(@actor.level/2),1))d8[healing]]{1d8 times half your level} (minimum 1d8).

Runt (1-2).name: Runt (1-2)

Runt (3-4).name: Runt (3-4)

Seldrick Dralston (1-2).description:
Deathless acolytes typically arise when a deity or their herald expends a minor amount of power to return a low-ranking priest. Some priests are powerful enough in life to return, greatly lessened, of their own volition.

Deathless acolytes are an oddity among undead, neither willingly transformed nor, strictly speaking, transformed against their will. The creation of a deathless acolyte is an act of direct intervention by a deity, typically as a double-edged reward and curse granted to a faithful priest who failed in completing a divine mandate due to circumstances beyond their control.

2ASu2r4ddMMqE7Y8.description: This piece of wood or silver is emblazoned with an image representing a deity. Some divine spellcasters, such as clerics, can use a religious symbol of their deity as a divine focus to use certain abilities and cast some spells. A religious symbol must be held in one hand to use it.
2ASu2r4ddMMqE7Y8.name: Broken Religious Symbol of Pharasma

7m7b3dwyednyhqtu.description:
Trigger A creature within 60 feet who Seldrick Dralston can see and who doesn't follow the Whispering Way casts a divine spell

Effect Seldrick attempts to counteract the triggering spell using their spell attack modifier and a counteract rank of 1. If Seldrick fails to counteract the spell, the caster is temporarily immune to further uses of Denounce Heretic for 24 hours.
7m7b3dwyednyhqtu.name: Denounce Heretic

JbI3fTQB8SNFx3jC.description:
This compact compass repurposes ancient technology to draw fantastic powers from the mysterious magical items called aeon stones. It serves as a badge of office for agents of the Pathfinder Society and as a status symbol among adventurers of any stripe. A wayfinder functions as a compass.

An indentation in the middle of the wayfinder can hold a single aeon stone. Placing an aeon stone in this indentation provides you all the benefits of having the aeon stone orbiting your head, but it protects the stone from being noticed or stolen as easily. You invest a wayfinder and the aeon stone within it simultaneously, and they count as only one item toward your investiture limit. An invested aeon stone slotted in a wayfinder also grants its resonant power.

If you have more than one wayfinder with an invested aeon stone on your person at a given time, destructive interference from their resonance prevents you from gaining benefits from any of them. You can still benefit from additional aeon stones orbiting your head, just not in wayfinders.

Activate A command

Effect The wayfinder is targeted by a 1st-rank @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.WBmvzNDfpwka3qT4]{Light} spell.

csccddk7b6n1491u.description: 20 feet. Allies within the aura who have void healing gain fast healing 2. When a creature within the aura would receive vitality healing, it must succeed at a @Check[flat|dc:5] or receive no healing from the effect.
csccddk7b6n1491u.name: Field of Undeath

Seldrick Dralston (1-2).name: Seldrick Dralston (1-2)

Deathless acolytes typically arise when a deity or their herald expends a minor amount of power to return a low-ranking priest. Some priests are powerful enough in life to return, greatly lessened, of their own volition.

This compact compass repurposes ancient technology to draw fantastic powers from the mysterious magical items called aeon stones. It serves as a badge of office for agents of the Pathfinder Society and as a status symbol among adventurers of any stripe. A wayfinder functions as a compass.

An indentation in the middle of the wayfinder can hold a single aeon stone. Placing an aeon stone in this indentation provides you all the benefits of having the aeon stone orbiting your head, but it protects the stone from being noticed or stolen as easily. You invest a wayfinder and the aeon stone within it simultaneously, and they count as only one item toward your investiture limit. An invested aeon stone slotted in a wayfinder also grants its resonant power.

If you have more than one wayfinder with an invested aeon stone on your person at a given time, destructive interference from their resonance prevents you from gaining benefits from any of them. You can still benefit from additional aeon stones orbiting your head, just not in wayfinders.

Activate A command

Effect The wayfinder is targeted by a 1st-rank @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.WBmvzNDfpwka3qT4]{Light} spell.

csccddk7b6n1491u.description: 20 feet. Allies within the aura who have void healing gain fast healing 3. When a creature within the aura would receive vitality healing, it must succeed at a @Check[flat|dc:5] or receive no healing from the effect.
csccddk7b6n1491u.name: Field of Undeath

Seldrick Dralston (3-4).name: Seldrick Dralston (3-4)

Serraleth.description: Rorus, sometimes called hunter demons, are brutal fiends that arise from the souls of mortals who mutilated animal corpses. As demons, these individuals don animal pelts, then infiltrate packs or herds to corrupt entire swaths of animals, turning their victims bloodthirsty and feral.

gafle2cabrnckhdn.description: 30 feet. An animal or beast entering or starting its turn in the emanation must succeed at a @Check[will|dc:25] save or become @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.TBSHQspnbcqxsmjL]{Frightened 1} (frightened 2 on a critical failure). Frightened animals within the emanation can't attack Serraleth. A creature that succeeds at a saving throw against predatory aura is immune for 24 hours.
gafle2cabrnckhdn.name: Predatory Aura

lo4ykwnhgn0sqzrn.description: The first time each round an attempt to Command an Animal fails within 60 feet of Serraleth, she takes @Damage[4d6[mental]] damage (@Damage[10d6[mental]] if Serraleth failed the attempt).
lo4ykwnhgn0sqzrn.name: Disobedience Vulnerability

or225f5ibefcz90w.description: Serraleth focuses her corruption on an animal or beast it can see within 30 feet. The creature must succeed at a @Check[will|dc:25] save or become @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.yblD8fOR1J8rDwEQ]{Confused} for [[/gmr 1d4 #rounds]]{1d4 rounds}. The confused creature can't attack Serraleth. A creature that succeeds at its saving throw is temporarily immune to Incite Ferocity for 24 hours.
or225f5ibefcz90w.name: Incite Ferocity

vfnb5vr7qkm2nzme.description: Serraleth dons the pelt of an adjacent dead animal, transforming into its lookalike. She becomes the same size and gains the same Speeds as the target animal. Serraleth loses her claw and jaws unarmed Strikes and gains the types of melee Strikes of the animal whose pelt she wears. The Strike deals damage equal to her jaws Strike or, if the Strike has the agile trait, her claw Strike. Either way, the damage type changes to match the new unarmed attack. While Serraleth wears a pelt, half of physical damage dealt to her is instead dealt to the pelt. A pelt has Hardness 5 and 25 HP. When a pelt reaches 0 HP, she's immediately expelled from the pelt and it's destroyed.
vfnb5vr7qkm2nzme.name: Wear Pelt

Shadow Cannon.description: A cannon built of cast iron and infused with shadow magic, mounted on the side of Aslynn's flying ship.
Shadow Cannon.hazardDisable: @Check[arcana|dc:20] or @Check[thievery|dc:20] on the cannon's body to deactivate
Shadow Cannon.hazardRoutine: (1 action) The cannon fires a blast that contains as many PCs as possible, choosing randomly in the event of a tie.
Shadow Cannon.name: Shadow Cannon

Shaitan Tactics (3-4).description: The shaitan observes the area from a distance, observing the battlefield as a game board. The ground trembles in response to the genie's enthusiasm.
Shaitan Tactics (3-4).hazardDisable: @Check[arcana|dc:20] (trained) or @Check[nature|dc:20] (trained) to contest the shaitan's control (requires two successes).
Shaitan Tactics (3-4).hazardReset: The trap deactivates and resets once all hostile creatures leave A3 or surrender.
Shaitan Tactics (3-4).hazardRoutine: (2 actions) On each of the trap's actions, the trap either moves a willing creature on the ground up to 30 feet without provoking reactions or makes a hostile creature on the ground @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.AJh5ex99aV6VTggg]{Off-Guard} for 1 round on a failed @Check[acrobatics|dc:20] check or @Check[reflex|dc:20] save.

FWTg5gFKBoDWE2bL.description:
Aslynn gazes upon a creature, afflicting it with intense distress and a gnawing sense of impending doom; the creature must attempt a @Check[will|dc:17] save. Since this effect isn't visual, the creature doesn't need to be able to see Aslynn to be affected.

Critical Success The target is unaffected and is temporarily immune to Aslynn's gaze for 1 day.

Success The target is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.TBSHQspnbcqxsmjL]{Frightened 1}.

Failure The target is frightened 1 and @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3]{Slowed 1} for 1 round.

Critical Failure The target is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.TBSHQspnbcqxsmjL]{Frightened 2} and slowed 1 for 1 minute.
FWTg5gFKBoDWE2bL.name: Aslynn's Gaze

qxBiKIiPp47G36tg.description: Wounds caused by Aslynn's claws cause creatures to dwell on their worst nightmares. A creature damaged by Aslynn's claw must succeed at a @Check[fortitude|dc:17] save or be @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.e1XGnhKNSQIm5IXg]{Stupefied 1} for 1 day. On a critical failure, or if it gets hit again and fails its save a second time, it's @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.e1XGnhKNSQIm5IXg]{Stupefied 2} for 1 day.
qxBiKIiPp47G36tg.name: Nightmarish Wounds

Shard of Aslynn (1-2).name: Shard of Aslynn (1-2)

Skeletal Pathfinder.description:
These soldiers continue to follow orders in death, still wielding the armaments they spent a lifetime learning how to use. While frequently made from the bones of humans or dwarves, other types of humanoids are quite common, such as bugbears, hobgoblins, and orcs. Often, these soldiers wield the weapons most common among their people instead of those listed here.

Among the ranks of the dead, none are so numerous, nor so varied, as the skeleton. While most are almost entirely made from bone, some maintain a few scraps of flesh to aid them in movement, such as wing membranes.

IKaE64DkfeEobVnG.description: Sometimes called a hauberk, this is a long shirt constructed of the same metal rings as chainmail. However, it is much lighter than chainmail and protects only the torso, upper arms, and upper legs of its wearer.

zhuzs5628vicodv5.description: The skeletal pathfinder sets its glaive (or other reach weapon) to defend the area around it. It gains the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-ability-glossary-srd.Item.hFtNbo1LKYCoDy2O]{Attack of Opportunity} reaction for that weapon only. This lasts until the skeleton takes an action with the move or attack trait or is destroyed.
zhuzs5628vicodv5.name: Set Defense

Skeletal Pathfinder.name: Skeletal Pathfinder

Skeletal Pathfinder Veteran.description:
These skeletons retain the cunning they possessed in life.

Made from bones held together by foul necromancy, skeletons are among the most common types of undead, found haunting old dungeons and forgotten cemeteries.
